title: 109_hr1637
content: The "Intermodal Transportation Act of 2005" may be cited as the official title. Chapter 55 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on intermodal passenger facilities. The "Intermodal Transportation Act of 2005" aims to enhance intermodal passenger facilities to improve public transportation efficiency and connectivity. It accelerates integration among North America's passenger transportation modes by ensuring access to intermodal terminals, promoting an integrated system of transportation information, and providing grants for intercity bus facilities. The "Intermodal Transportation Act of 2005" defines a capital project as acquiring, constructing, improving, or renovating intermodal facilities related to intercity bus service to enhance coordination with other modes of transportation. This includes physical infrastructure like building construction, special lanes, and curb cuts. The "Intermodal Transportation Act of 2005" defines capital projects for intercity bus service as acquiring, constructing, improving, or renovating facilities to enhance coordination with other modes of transportation. This includes building construction, special lanes, curb cuts, ticket kiosks, passenger waiting areas, baggage storage, employee parking, office space, security, and signage. It also involves establishing or enhancing coordination between intercity bus service and other transportation modes. The term 'intermodal passenger facility' refers to a terminal that can accommodate various modes of transportation, including intercity rail, commuter bus or rail, intercity bus, and local public transportation. The term 'local governmental authority' includes political subdivisions of a State, authorities of a State or political subdivision, Indian tribes, and public corporations. The term 'owner or operator of a public transportation facility' refers to those operating intercity-rail, intercity-bus, commuter-rail, rail-transit, bus-transit, or ferry services. The term 'recipient' encompasses any public or private entity. The term 'recipient' refers to any entity receiving a grant directly from the Federal Government. The term 'Secretary' pertains to the Secretary of Transportation. The term 'State' includes various regions within the United States. The term 'urban area' denotes an area suitable for a local public transportation system. Section 5573 ensures access to intermodal passenger facilities for intercity buses and other transportation modes funded by the public. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants for intercity bus intermodal passenger facility projects, with a maximum grant of 80% of the project cost. Grants are awarded through a competitive selection process, and recipients must demonstrate financial commitment to justify the project. Funding for projects not covered by this section can come from various sources such as cash reserves or new capital, including federal funds for transportation. Grants funded under section 5575(a) create a contractual obligation for the US government. The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations for implementation. Funding for this subchapter is authorized from the Mass Transit Account of the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006-2009. In 2009, $75,000,000 was allocated from the Mass Transit Account of the Highway Trust Fund, with a limit of $5,000,000 for specific purposes. An additional $10,000,000 was authorized annually from the Highway Trust Fund for section 5571(b)(3) projects from 2006 to 2009. The funds are subject to obligation limitations and follow section 5309 requirements. Amounts allocated under subsection (a) of this section remain available until expended. The table of contents for chapter 55 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include a new subchapter on intermodal passenger facilities.
